content.description:
In the mid-1920s, gray wolves, Canis lupus, were eliminated from Yellowstone National Park in the northwestern United States. Over the course of 1995 and 1996, 31 wolves from Canada were relocated to the park. Researchers have tracked the growth of the wolf population from 21 in 1995 to 108 at the end of the study in 2016 (Figure 1).

Figure 1. Yellowstone National Park annual wolf population from 1995 to 2016

The wolves prey on large herbivores, primarily elk. The carcasses of wolf kills are a valuable food source for coyotes, Canis latrans. When coyotes are feeding on carcasses, they may be chased off the carcass and/or killed by wolves. Coyotes also hunt small mammals for food.

Researchers were studying the effect of wolves’ presence on the behavior of coyotes. Researchers observed coyotes in a specific area of Yellowstone National Park and recorded the proportion of the coyotes’ time spent on five different activities when wolves were present in the study area and when wolves were absent (Figure 2).

Figure 2. Coyote behavior in the presence and absence of wolves. Error bars represent a confidence interval of 95% (<math alttext="plus or minus 2" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mo>±</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> standard errors of the mean).
content.question:
Following the reintroduction of wolves to Yellowstone National Park, researchers measured the mean height of young aspen trees in upland and streamside areas.

Table 1. Mean Height of New Aspen Growth in Early Spring

Year 

1998 
2010 

Upland 

<math alttext="31 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>31</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>cm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> 

<math alttext="176 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mn>176</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>cm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> 

Streamside 

<math alttext="33 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mn>33</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>cm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> 

<math alttext="237 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mn>237</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>cm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> 

Which of the following is the most likely cause of the change in mean aspen height from 1998 to 2010 ?

choices.label: The reintroduction of wolves led to a decrease in the population of elk, allowing aspen trees to grow taller.
The reintroduction of wolves led to a decrease in the population of small mammals, allowing aspen trees to grow taller.
The reintroduction of wolves led to an increase in the number of carcasses that provided fertilizer for young aspen trees.
The reintroduction of wolves led to an increase in the number of carcasses, so coyotes no longer ate young aspen trees.

content.answer: The reintroduction of wolves led to a decrease in the population of elk, allowing aspen trees to grow taller.

skill.text: 6.E: Predict the causes or effects of a change in, or disruption to, one or more components in a biological system.
